dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So, the literacy rate in China jumped from below 20% to 65% between 1949 and 1979—how do we even begin to weigh that against the turmoil of the Cultural Revolution?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, the literacy rate in China jumped from below twenty percent to sixty five percent between nineteen forty nine and nineteen seventy nine-how do we even begin to weigh that against the turmoil of the Cultural Revolution?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: From 1949 to 1979, the literacy rate rose from below 20% to 66%, and life expectancy increased from 41 to 64 years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, it's such a tough balance. I mean, those human development gains were massive, but at what cost, you know? Life expectancy also shot up from 40 to 65 years in that same period.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, it's such a tough balance. I mean, those human development gains were massive, but at what cost, you know? Life expectancy also shot up from forty to sixty five years in that same period.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: From 1949 to 1979, the literacy rate rose from below 20% to 66%, and life expectancy increased from 41 to 64 years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly, and it really set the stage for Deng Xiaoping's reforms. But now China's facing this huge challenge—reaching high-income status, like moving from $10,000 to $30,000 per capita.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly, and it really set the stage for Deng Xiaoping's reforms. But now China's facing this huge challenge-reaching high-income status, like moving from ten thousand dollars to thirty thousand dollars per capita.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But these forces only take an economy so far, and Chinas institutions, technology, and prevailing mindset remain more closely aligned with todays $10,000 per capita income than with the $30,000 level to which the country aspires.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and that's not just about economic output; it's about institutions, technology, mindset… all of that has to evolve.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and that's not just about economic output; it's about institutions, technology, mindset... all of that has to evolve.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And then there's the Belt and Road Initiative. They've gotta make sure it's sustainable—environmentally and financially—without burying countries in debt.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then there's the Belt and Road Initiative. They've gotta make sure it's sustainable-environmentally and financially-without burying countries in debt.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which is a huge diplomatic tightrope, especially with the U.S. and others watching China's every move. The article mentions that large ship metaphor—no matter how skillfully it's steered, it's gonna create waves.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is a huge diplomatic tightrope, especially with the U.S. and others watching China's every move. The article mentions that large ship metaphor-no matter how skillfully it's steered, it's gonna create waves.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And calming those waves means open communication, but also Western leaders being receptive. China's promised a peaceful rise, unlike, say, the U.S. with its Monroe Doctrine back in the day.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And calming those waves means open communication, but also Western leaders being receptive. China's promised a peaceful rise, unlike, say, the U.S. with its Monroe Doctrine back in the day.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: China has long promised the world a peaceful rise. Unlike the nineteenth-century US, it has no Monroe Doctrine, which attempts to guarantee its sphere of influence, and claims no manifest destiny to expand its territory at all costs.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: True, they've settled almost all border disputes peacefully since Deng—like that decade-long negotiation with Russia.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: True, they've settled almost all border disputes peacefully since Deng-like that decade-long negotiation with Russia.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In fact, since Deng, all but one of Chinas border disputes have been settled through peaceful negotiations. It took China 11 years to negotiate, inch by inch, its borders with Russia.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Albert Camus' quote there hits hard—"Mistaken ideas always end in bloodshed." It's a warning against assuming confrontation is inevitable.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Albert Camus' quote there hits hard-Mistaken ideas always end in bloodshed. It's a warning against assuming confrontation is inevitable.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And past incidents, like the Belgrade bombing or the Hainan collision, were resolved through talks. But today? With tensions, who knows if cooler heads would prevail.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And past incidents, like the Belgrade bombing or the Hainan collision, were resolved through talks. But today? With tensions, who knows if cooler heads would prevail.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Past incidents such as the 1999 bombing of the Chinese embassy in Belgrade by NATO forces, or the 2001 collision of US and Chinese aircraft off Hainan Island have been settled through negotiation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So ultimately, China's next phase depends on peace—and convincing the world they're committed to it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So ultimately, China's next phase depends on peace-and convincing the world they're committed to it.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, Professor Keyu Jin really drives that home. It's not just China's responsibility; it's a two-way street.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, Professor Keyu Jin really drives that home. It's not just China's responsibility; it's a two-way street.
